H0.text: Which chemical element is named after a university in Oakland, California. Californium

H1.text: Which chemical element is named after a university in Oakland, California. Lawrencium

H2.text: Which chemical element is named after a university in Oakland, California. Seaborgium

H3.text: Which chemical element is named after a university in Oakland, California. Berkelium

A4.text: It is named after the city of Berkeley, California, the location of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (then the University of California Radiation Laboratory) where it was discovered in December 1949.

A5.text: The naming of the next discovered actinide, californium, was not related to its lanthanide analogue dysprosium, but after the discovery place.

A6.text: The University of California, Berkeley is a public land‑grant research university in the Southside and Northside neighborhoods of Berkeley, California, United States.

A7.text: Sixteen elements have been discovered at Berkeley (technetium, astatine, neptunium, plutonium, americium, curium, berkelium, californium, einsteinium, fermium, mendelevium, nobelium, lawrencium, rutherfordium, dubnium, and seaborgium).

A8.text: Glenn T. Seaborg discovered or co‑discovered ten chemical elements at Berkeley and served as chancellor from 1958 to 1961.

A9.text: Using the cyclotron, Berkeley professors and Berkeley Lab researchers went on to discover sixteen chemical elements—more than any other university in the world.
